item.title: Determinations of Attainment, Failure to Attain and Reclassifications for the 2006 24-Hour PM Standards
item.description:
On December 1, 2016 , the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency proposed determinations for 11 nonattainment areas classified as Moderate for the 2006 24-Hour Fine Particulate Matter National Ambient Air Quality Standards.  Based on requirements under the Clean Air Act, these areas were required to meet the standard by December 31, 2015.

item.title: PM25 NAAQS Final SIP Requirements Rule July 2016
item.description:
This rule establishes planning requirements for states with areas that do not meet the National Ambient Air Quality Standards for fine particle pollution. These states must develop plans that demonstrate how they will meet the standards. This rule allows states to rely on common-sense strategies to implement particle pollution standards, and it also responds to a January 2013 court decision on EPA’s previous rules implementing the fine particle pollution standards. 

Final PM Implementation Rule

Webinar Recording - PM2.5 NAAQS: Final SIP Requirements Rule - Aug 16, 2016 (presentation slides are available below)

item.title: Particulate Matter (PM) Implementation Regulatory Actions
item.description:
The Clean Air Act requires EPA to set National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) for six criteria pollutants; particle pollution (also known as particulate matter) is one of these.  EPA works with partners at state, local, and tribal air quality agencies to meet these standards.

The following list provides a collection of rules and guidance documents for implementation the more recent particulate matter (PM) standards.

  • PM-2.5
  • PM-2.5 (2006)
  • PM-2.5 (1997) - To find implementation information and guidance documents for the 1997 PM NAAQS, go to archive.epa.gov and use the search term "PM Implementation NAAQS."
  • PM-10 (1987) - To find implementation information and guidance documents for the 1987 PM NAAQS, go to archive.epa.gov and use the search term "PM Implementation NAAQS."
  • General Preamble for the Implementation of Title 1 of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990

To see a table of all of the PM NAAQS visit our Historical Particulate Matter (PM) National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) page.

item.description:
On This Page:

PM Nonattainment

  • Moderate Areas

  • Serious Areas that Fail to Attain

PM Nonattainment Area Requirements

Moderate Areas

All SIP elements due 18 months after initial designation:
  • Attainment Demonstration or Impracticability Demonstration
  • Base Year Emissions Inventory
  • Attainment Projected Emissions Inventory
  • RACM/RACT
  • Additional Reasonable Measures
  • Reasonable Further Progress
  • Quantitative Milestones
  • Contingency Measures
  • Nonattainment NSR

Top of Page

Serious Areas

  • Mandatory reclassification to Serious pursuant to CAA Section 188(b)(1). All SIP elements due 18 months after reclassification:
    • Attainment Demonstration
    • Base Year Emissions Inventory
    • Attainment Projected Emissions Inventory
    • BACM/BACT
    • Additional Feasible Measures
    • Reasonable Further Progress
    • Quantitative Milestones
    • Contingency Measures
    • Nonattainment NSR
  • Discretionary reclassification to Serious pursuant to CAA Section 188(b)(2).
    • SIP elements due 18 months after reclassification:
      • Attainment Demonstration
      • Base Year Emissions Inventory
      • BACM/BACT
      • Nonattainment NSR
    • SIP elements due at the earlier of 4 years from the date of reclassification, or the end of the eighth calendar year after designation:
      • Attainment Projected Emissions Inventory
      • Additional Feasible Measures
      • Reasonable Further Progress
      • Quantitative Milestones
      • Contingency Measures

Top of Page

Serious Areas That Fail to Attain

SIP elements due within 12 months after the missed applicable attainment date:
  • Attainment Demonstration
  • Base Year Emissions Inventory
  • Attainment Projected Emissions Inventory
  • MSM
  • Reasonable Further Progress
  • Quantitative Milestones
  • Contingency Measures

Top of Page

See the nonattainment state and national reports for the status of state submissions to meet these requirements, and EPA's actions on the submissions:
  • Status of SIP requirements, listed by state
  • National status of state SIP requirements

item.title: Specific Elements for Each of the Major SIP Types for Particulate Matter (PM)
item.description:
Infrastructure State Implementation Plan (SIP)

An infrastructure SIP, or i-SIP, is a requirement for all states, regardless of designation. Even areas in attainment must demonstrate what controls they will continue to use and regulate in order to remain in attainment.

Nonattainment New Source Review SIP

  • EPA's New Source Review (NSR) program requires major stationary sources of air pollution in nonattainment areas to get permits before construction starts:
    • Search the NSR Policy and Guidance Document Index (hint: use the Filter box at the top right of the index to search titles by keyword)
    • RACT/BACT/LAER Clearinghouse (RBLC): database of control technologies for achieving the lowest achievable emission rate (LAER)
  • Startup, shutdown, and malfunction (SSM) emissions

Nonattainment Area SIP

  • If an area is designated as nonattainment, the state must develop an additional SIP detailing the path to attainment. The SIP will require different elements depending on how far the area is from being able to reach attainment.
    • Nonattainment SIP requirements for PM

Interstate transport SIP

  • Interstate Air Pollution Transport: upwind transport of pollutants across state borders makes it difficult for downwind states to meet health-based air quality standards for PM.
    • Cross-State Air Pollution Rule (CSAPR) provides the regulatory basis for reducing interstate air pollution.

Redesignation SIP, or maintenance SIP

  • Redesignations and Clean Data Policies
  • Demonstrate attainment using air quality modeling and other analyses
